More generally,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
socratic_questions:
1. Can you explain what each matrix in the given expression represents and how matrix multiplication works?
2. What is the resulting matrix when you multiply the first two matrices? Can you generalize this result when multiplying any two matrices of the given form?
3. How does the third matrix multiplication affect the result? Can you find a pattern or general rule for multiplying matrices of this form?
4. Based on the pattern you observed, what can you predict about the final result of multiplying all the given matrices together?
5. Can you prove your prediction using mathematical induction or another method?
6. Can you think of any other matrices that can be simplified using a similar approach of multiplying matrices of the given form in a series?
